importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start of a period of intensified Western sanctions on Iran under the Obama administration, marking a turning point in the impact of sanctions on Iran's economy and middle class.
The signing of the JCPOA (Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action) nuclear deal, which temporarily eased sanctions, but was followed by a resurgence of pressure under the Trump administration.
The reimposition of severe sanctions under President Donald Trump's 'maximum pressure' policy, leading to renewed economic hardship for the Iranian middle class and increased inequality.
The current state of economic distress and societal unrest in Iran, with ongoing inflation, unemployment, and political shifts reflecting long-term damage from sanctions since 2012.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period saw the most significant economic and social impact of Western sanctions on Iran, including a 17% projected shrinkage of the middle class had sanctions not existed, and a sharp rise in inequality.

keyTakeAways: Western sanctions on Iran have severely damaged the middle class, which historically drove political reform and stability in Iran.

The Iranian middle class, composed of educated professionals, teachers, and civil servants, has shrunk by 28% between 2012 and 2019 due to sanctions, with an estimated 9 million people losing middle-class status.

Sanctions have led to rising inflation (42.4% in October 2025), high unemployment (7.4%–9.2%), and a sharp increase in wealth disparity, with luxury services accessible to the elite while basic goods become unaffordable.

The shift in political engagement from middle-class reform demands to working-class survival protests reflects a deeper societal fracture, making protests more volatile and vulnerable to state repression.
The perception of inequality is more dangerous than actual inequality and undermines national unity and long-term political stability.
Sanctions have redirected economic power to state-linked actors like the IRGC and bonyads, weakening independent entrepreneurship and strengthening hardline political power.
Without a generational effort, rebuilding the middle class is a long-term challenge, even if sanctions are lifted.

namedEntities.name: Iran
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in the Middle East with a population of around 92 million, which has faced sustained Western sanctions since 1979.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Iran is the central case study in the article, showing how Western sanctions have devastated its middle class and disrupted political stability.

namedEntities.name: Western sanctions
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Economic restrictions imposed by Western countries, especially the United States and Europe, on Iran since the 1979 revolution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article argues that these sanctions have directly harmed the Iranian middle class, which was historically a force for reform and moderation.

namedEntities.name: Middle class in Iran
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A large, educated segment of Iranian society composed of teachers, civil servants, professionals, and entrepreneurs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group has been systematically weakened by sanctions, leading to reduced political participation, rising inequality, and a shift in protest movements.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Reza Pahlavi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Shah of Iran, overthrown in 1979, whose removal paved the way for clerical rule and long-term political changes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His overthrow marked the beginning of Iran’s modern political structure, including the rise of the middle class through education and opportunity.

namedEntities.name: JCPOA (Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nuclear agreement between Iran and world powers in 2015 that temporarily eased sanctions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided a short-lived respite from sanctions, but its collapse under the Trump administration in 2018 led to renewed economic hardship.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former U.S. President who reimposed sanctions on Iran in 2018 under his 'maximum pressure' policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His policies intensified economic suffering in Iran, accelerating the decline of the middle class and deepening inequality.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Khatami
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Iranian president (1997–2005) who gained support from the middle class and was a reformist leader.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He exemplifies the historical role of the middle class in driving reform movements in Iran.

namedEntities.name: Hassan Rouhani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Iranian president (2013–2021) who also drew support from the middle class and promoted reformist policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His leadership reflects the middle class’s ongoing influence in political change, now weakened by sanctions.

namedEntities.name: Masoud Pezeshkian
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Current Iranian president (as of 2025), who continues to draw on reformist support.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The decline of the middle class undermines his ability to mobilize broad-based reformist support.

namedEntities.name: Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A powerful military and political branch of Iran’s government that holds economic and ideological power.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sanctions have strengthened the IRGC by diverting resources to state-linked actors, entrenching hardline power and reducing civil society influence.

namedEntities.name: Bonyads
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Government-backed charitable trusts in Iran that receive state funding and distribute resources.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These institutions have benefited from sanctions, further concentrating wealth and power within state-aligned structures.

namedEntities.name: European Journal of Political Economy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A peer-reviewed academic journal where a study on the impact of sanctions on Iran was published.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The study provides the primary evidence for the article’s claims about the shrinking middle class due to sanctions.

namedEntities.name: International Monetary Fund (IMF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international financial organization that reports on Iran’s inflation and unemployment rates.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: IMF data is used to quantify economic hardship, including 42.4% inflation and 9.2% unemployment in 2025.

namedEntities.name: Leila Gharagozlou
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CNN journalist who authored the article.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the source of the reporting, providing firsthand insight and interviews with Iranian individuals.

namedEntities.name: Sina Toossi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Senior fellow at the Center for International Policy, who analyzes the political effects of sanctions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His expertise supports the argument that sanctions have shifted power toward hardline state actors like the IRGC.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Reza Farzanegan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of economics at the University of Marburg, one of the study’s authors.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides key research findings showing that sanctions have reduced the middle class by 28% and altered political dynamics.

namedEntities.name: Nader Habibi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of economics at Brandeis University, co-author of the study on sanctions and Iran.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He contributes to the academic foundation of the article's claims about economic impacts of sanctions.

namedEntities.name: Elham
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A schoolteacher in Tehran who speaks about economic hardship and rising inequality.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her testimony illustrates the lived experience of middle-class Iranians under sanctions.

namedEntities.name: Reza
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 36-year-old Iranian resident who could not flee Tehran after Israel’s bombing due to fuel shortages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His experience highlights the economic and social vulnerability of ordinary citizens under sanctions and conflict.

namedEntities.name: Ali
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 34-year-old computer engineer in Tehran who struggles to find employment.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His story exemplifies the difficulty of maintaining livelihoods in a shrinking middle class with limited opportunities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Western sanctions on Iran, especially since 2012, have significantly harmed the country’s middle class — a historically moderate and reform-oriented group that once drove political stability and social progress. A study using a synthetic control method found that, without sanctions, the Iranian middle class would have grown by 17%, but in reality, it shrank by 28% by 2019, with around 9 million people losing middle-class status. Economic pressures from inflation (42.4%), high unemployment (7.4%–9.2%), and rising costs of basic goods have deepened inequality, leaving many to struggle with daily survival. The elite, including state-linked actors like the IRGC and bonyads, have profited from the economic downturn, while the middle class has lost its economic security and political influence. This shift has transformed protest movements from reform-focused to survival-driven, increasing instability and making them more vulnerable to repression. Experts warn that rebuilding the middle class is a generational challenge, as the damage from sanctions has fundamentally altered Iran’s social and political fabric.
title: How Western sanctions on Iran have hurt the same middle class that drives reform
